node.messageHeadline: embed TCP graphics server in PyBullet for easier working-from-home
node.message:
embed TCP graphics server in PyBullet for easier working-from-home
This allows to render at a different machine, sending all assets across the TCP network, using port 6667 by default.
You can use ssh port forwarding to get this working:
ssh -R 6667:localhost:6667 username@remotehost.com -v

python3 -m pybullet_utils.graphicsServer
python3 -m pybullet_utils.graphicsClient

Note that there are still some tcp networking issues that can cause a hang, just restart graphics server and graphics client if it hangs.

node.messageHeadline: Include dlerror() in handling of failed dlopen()
node.message:
Include dlerror() in handling of failed dlopen()

X11OpenGLWindow::X11OpenGLWindow() ends up calling dlopen() to get libX11.
When this fails, it only reports that it failed, and what filename it was looking for.
This commit adds dlerror() to the error message, which makes investigating failures easier.

node.messageHeadline: Add memory tests for convex and compound shapes.
node.message: Add memory tests for convex and compound shapes.

node.messageHeadline: Track and destroy noncached shapes. Clean up.
node.message: Track and destroy noncached shapes. Clean up.

node.messageHeadline: Track and clean up motion states.
node.message: Track and clean up motion states.

Cleaner material handling

_materials was never actually being assigned to. _materials_ref_count
now counts how many times a material has been used in the scene and
removes it from itself and the web worker if the last object a material
is associated with gets removed. Before physijs materials never got
removed from the web worker.

Increases removeObject() memory performance #95

The worker's heap is still growing which is a problem, but this
substantially increases memory performance (as tested with OS X/Chrome)
and changes the crash from a sad tab to a hang in the worker (at
137,000 boxes).

More aggressive block spawning

Still careful to wait for "ready" so that the engine doesn't get
overwhelmed. There is the risk of deleting an object before it is
ready, but as long as max_on_screen is larger than spawn_per_tick it
should be fine. And that shouldn't really be possible given the
requency of message passing back and fourth between the page thread and
the worker.

Merge pull request #38 from MichaelMoroz/patch-1

Ray marching performance patch

Updated filtering

Now it samples on the surface of the fractal in the direction of the ray insead of a tetrahedron, since sometimes the tetrahedron technique can give incorect coloring(the color changes very fast in the direction of the surface normal)

node.messageHeadline: Minor fixes and added texture filtering
node.message: Minor fixes and added texture filtering

Removed abs(d)

It caused artifacts when the camera intersected the fractal.

Ray marching performance update

The main change is in the "ray has hit the surface" condition, I modified it, so the marching stops when the ray is closer then the visible distance per pixel from the camera at this position. Since we march far less steps it gives quite a considerable performance boost. In my case it was about 20-100% more fps, depending on the distance from the fractal. It didn't work by itself though, since it gave some weird graphical artifacts, the problem was in the fact that the point was too far from the fractal surface, so I added an additional step to march in the opposite direction of the surface normal to get to the closest surface point. (Actually, isn't it simpler to find the collisions between the marble and the fractal in this way?)  
Also I added a faster numerical normal function, it uses 4 DE calculations instead of 6, credit to Inigo Quilez.

node.messageHeadline: Ensure passed canvas abides by render options
node.message:
Ensure passed canvas abides by render options

Engine.create takes a canvas element or creates a new canvas using the
given options. While the properties width and height in options do apply
to the created canvas, they do not apply to the passed canvas. These set
options are under render.canvas, render.options.width and
render.options.height. This issue was fixed by setting the canvas width
and height only when a canvas element is directly provided.
